snips: Subscribe to Observables in order but only when the previous completes
name: concat

snips: Donâ€™t let me know until all the Observables are complete, then give me all the values at once. ( Array )
name: forkJoin

snips: Only when the inner Observable emits, let me know by merging the value to the outer Observable.
name: mergeMap

snips: Let me know when the Observable emits, but also give me the previous value. ( Array )
name: pairwise

snips: Like mergeMap but when the source Observable emits cancel any previous subscriptions of the inner Observable
name: switchMap

snips: Let me know when any Observable emits but also give me the latest value from the others. ( Array )
name: combineLatest

snips: Perform a side effect for every emission on the source Observable, but return an Observable that is identical to the source
name: tap

snips: Maps each source value (an object) to its specified nested property.
name: pluck

snips: Emits a value from the source Observable only after a particular time span determined by another Observable has passed without another source emission
name: debounce

snips: Emits a value from the source Observable, then ignores subsequent source values for a duration determined by another Observable, then repeats this process
name: throttle

outputs: calls a function once for each element in an array, in order.
name: forEach

outputs: creates an array filled with all array elements that pass a test (provided as a function)
name: filter

outputs: sorts the items of an array.
name: sort

outputs: returns the value of the first element in an array that pass a test (provided as a function)
name: find

outputs: removes the last element of an array, and returns that element.
name: pop

outputs: removes the first item of an array.
name: shift

outputs: returns the selected elements in an array, as a new array object.
name: slice

snips: let output = this.firstname + ' '+ this.lastname +' is lived in ' + city + ', '+ province + ', '+ country;
outputs: Roger Huang is lived in Markham, Ontario, Canada

snips: if(wontDo) log.innerHTML += promiseCount +') Do not want do my job(<small>Start looking at the task</small>)';
else log.innerHTML += promiseCount +') Started doing my job(<small>Beging my task</small>)';
).then((val) =>log.innerHTML += val +') My job is done (<small>promise fullfiled and ended</small>)')
name: promise

outputs: returns an array of object keys.
name: Object.keys

outputs: Sends only upcoming values; A Subject doesn't hold a value;
name: Subjects

outputs: Sends one previous value and upcoming values; A BehaviorSubject holds one value.
When it is subscribed it emits the value immediately; BehaviorSubject can be created with initial value: new Rx.BehaviorSubject(1) You can get current value synchronously by subject.value;
BehaviorSubject is the best for 90% of the cases to store current value comparing to other Subject types;
name: BehaviorSubject

outputs: Sends all previous values and upcoming values
name: ReplaySubject

outputs: Sends one latest value when the stream will close
name: AsyncSubject

outputs: The flex-direction property defines in which direction the container wants to stack the flex items.
name: flex-direction

outputs: The flex-wrap property specifies whether the flex items should wrap or not.
name: flex-wrap

outputs: The flex-flow property is a shorthand property for setting both the flex-direction and flex-wrap properties.
name: flex-flow

outputs: The justify-content property is used to align the flex items:
name: justify-content

outputs: The align-items property is used to align the flex items vertically.
name: align-items

outputs: The align-content property is used to align the flex lines.
name: align-content

outputs: The order property specifies the order of the flex items.
name: order

outputs: The flex-grow property specifies how much a flex item will grow relative to the rest of the flex items.
name: flex-grow

outputs: The flex-shrink property specifies how much a flex item will shrink relative to the rest of the flex items.
An element with a flex-shrink value of 0 will not shrink as our page gets smaller. This is only true if there is no flex-grow value on this element.
If there is a flex-grow value, the element wonâ€™t shrink smaller than itâ€™s content
name: flex-shrink

outputs: The flex-basis property specifies the initial length of a flex item.
name: flex-basis

outputs: The flex property is a shorthand property for the flex-grow, flex-shrink, and flex-basis properties.
flex: 1 0 200px;

If you have one element that has a flex-basis of 200px, flex-grow of 1, and flex-shrink of 0, this element will be at minimum 200px wide, but it will be allowed to grow if there is extra space. In this case, you can think of the flex-basis as being a minimum width.
flex: 0 1 200px;

Letâ€™s consider the opposite case. Letâ€™s set a flex-basis of 200px again, but letâ€™s only set a flex-shrink of 1, flex-grow will be 0. Here we will have an element that is 200px at itâ€™s largest, but itâ€™s allowed to be smaller. Here flex-basis is acting like a maximum width.
name: flex

outputs: The align-self property specifies the alignment for the selected item inside the flexible container.
name: align-self

outputs: The ::first-line pseudo-element is used to add a special style to the first line of a text.
name: first-line

outputs: The ::first-letter pseudo-element is used to add a special style to the first letter of a text.
name: first-letter

outputs: The ::before pseudo-element can be used to insert some content before the content of an element.
name: before

outputs: The ::after pseudo-element can be used to insert some content after the content of an element.
name: after

outputs: The ::selection pseudo-element matches the portion of an element that is selected by a user.
name: selection

outputs: a:active	Selects the active link
name: active

outputs: input:checked	Selects every checked <input> element
name: checked

outputs: input:disabled	Selects every disabled <input> element
name: disabled

outputs: p:empty	Selects every <p> element that has no children
name: empty

outputs: input:enabled	Selects every enabled <input> element
name: enabled

outputs: p:first-child	Selects every <p> elements that is the first child of its parent
name: first-child

outputs: p:first-of-type	Selects every<p> element that is the first <p> element of its parent
name: first-of-type

outputs: input:focus	Selects the <input> element that has focus
name: focus

outputs: a:hover	Selects links on mouse over
name: hover

outputs: input:in-range	Selects <input> elements with a value within a specified range
name: in-range

outputs: input:invalid	Selects all <input> elements with an invalid value
name: invalid

outputs: p:lang(it)	Selects every <p> element with a lang attribute value starting with "it"
name: lang()

outputs: p:last-child	Selects every <p> elements that is the last child of its parent
name: last-child

outputs: p:last-of-type	Selects every <p> element that is the last <p> element of its parent
name: last-of-type

outputs: a:link	Selects all unvisited links
name: link

outputs: :not(p)	Selects every element that is not a <p> element
name: not()

outputs: p:nth-child(2)	Selects every <p> element that is the second child of its parent
name: nth-child()

outputs: p:nth-last-child(2)	Selects every <p> element that is the second child of its parent, counting from the last child
name: nth-last-child()

outputs: p:nth-last-of-type(2)	Selects every <p> element that is the second <p> element of its parent, counting from the last child
name: nth-last-of-type()

outputs: p:nth-of-type(2)	Selects every <p> element that is the second <p> element of its parent
name: nth-of-type()

outputs: p:only-of-type	Selects every <p> element that is the only <p> element of its parent
name: only-of-type

outputs: p:only-child	Selects every <p> element that is the only child of its parent
name: only-child

outputs: input:optional	Selects <input> elements with no "required" attribute
name: optional

outputs: input:out-of-range	Selects <input> elements with a value outside a specified range
name: out-of-range

outputs: input:read-only	Selects <input> elements with a "readonly" attribute specified
name: read-only

outputs: input:read-write	Selects <input> elements with no "readonly" attribute
name: read-write

outputs: input:required	Selects <input> elements with a "required" attribute specified
name: required

outputs: Selects the document's root element
name: root

outputs: #news:target	Selects the current active #news element (clicked on a URL containing that anchor name)
name: target

outputs: input:valid	Selects all <input> elements with a valid value
name: valid

outputs: a:visited	Selects all visited links
name: visited
